campaign.title: #TripleTakeTim
campaign.subtitle: 12 months of continued training, casting director connection, and brand building.
mission: Every month post a new scene with three distinct takes
Send 3 takes of every scene to every audition (when appropriate)
Connect with casting directors through consistent quality content
Continue to train and establish a professional brand
campaign.heroText: Monthly scene work exploring character choices, objectives, and technique

scenes.title: History of Bricks
scenes.description: Scene from "Still Up" (Apple TV) - Alex calls Jamie after finally getting Poppy to sleep by reading The History of Bricks. He's proud, a little insecure, and holding on to the small wins.
scenes.learnings: Played with how small external choices shift character energy. The tattoo sleeve and earring in Take 2 brought out Alex's different mood, while the straightforward US accent in Take 1 grounded him. Breaking self-tape convention with portrait framing in Take 3 created intimacy - the vertical format naturally pulled me closer to the camera, making the late-night call feel more real to me, possibly also paired with using my own accent.
scenes.behindTheScenes: Shot all three takes in one session but completely reset between each - changing costume, adjusting lighting, and rotating the phone for Take 3. The portrait format was a risk but it mirrors how we actually FaceTimeand I enjoyed that intimacy.

scenes.title: Woolongong
scenes.description: Scene from the Australian TV movie "Timothy" (2014) - a former investment banker who lost everything in China reconnects with an old mate from 20 years ago in Wollongong, navigating shame, pride, and the awkwardness of vastly different life trajectories.
scenes.learnings: Explored how levels of acceptance, control vs. chaos, social investment, and presence vs. escape can be communicated through both performance choices and visual elements like hair, costume, and energy.
scenes.behindTheScenes: Each take uses different visual storytelling approaches - hair, costume, and energy - to support the character's internal state and relationship to his circumstances.

scenes.title: Bad News Bear
scenes.description: Scene from "The Bear" - experimenting with costume, framing, and US accent work while maintaining consistent core tone across different visual presentations.
scenes.learnings: Discovered how visual shifts (costume and framing) can affect delivery even when the core emotional tone remains consistent. Practiced US accent work across multiple takes.
scenes.behindTheScenes: A fly joined the set during one take, which I incorporated into the scene as an improv moment!
